Lund Institute of Technology, P.O. Box 124, S-221 WLund (Sweden) Summary TiOg(B) was used as a support for vanadium oxide with loadings in the range 1/4 to 10 theoretical layers. The vanadium could be separated into two parts, which were soluble and insoluble in NHsCaq), respectively. Insoluble vanadium, in an amount corresponding to a complete monolayer at high loadings, was present as V44' in freshly prepared catalysts. Diffuse reflectance FTIR spectroscopy was used to characterize the catalysts. The bands assigned to stretching vibrations of hydroxyl groups on TiOgCB) were found to decrease in intensity with increasing vanadium loading. Spectra in the V=0 and V 0 V vibration region revealed a rather complex growth pattern. For a catalyst covered with a complete monolayer, vanadium strongly interacting with the support is present as interconnected tetrahedral V4"1' units. When the loading is increased, several additional layers of V5"1' in tetrahedral coordination can exist on top of the monolayer. At higher loadings, there is an abrupt change in structure, resulting in the formation of an amorphous phase built up from distorted VOe octahedra. Also, crystalline Va05 is formed. The catalysts were used in the ammoxidation of toluene to benzonitrile. Multilayer catalysts showed better catalytic performance in comparison with crystalline Vz05 and catalysts exposing monolayer species. Introduction In selective oxidation of alkyi aromatic compounds, vanadium oxide- containing catalysts are generally used [1,2]. These catalysts are also active in the ammoxidation of the same compounds to their corresponding nitriles. This is due to the mechanistic similarities of the oxidation and ammoxidation pathways [3]. In both types of reaction, abstraction of a hydrogen atom from the methyl group is followed by an insertion of a nucleophilic species. In oxidation, an O2" species is inserted, while in ammoxidation an isoelectronic imido species is believed to be added to the activated hydrocarbon [4,5]. Studies of ammoxidation reactions, therefore, can contribute to a wider understanding of oxidation catalysis. 0304-5102/90/$3.50 Elsevier Sequoia/Printed in The Netherlands 234 Pure vanadium oxides usually have relatively low specific surface areas [6]. To increase their feasibility for industrial use, they are fixed to supports having comparatively high specific surface areas. It is well known that the anatase modification of TiOg is suitable as a support, not only because of its high surface area, but also because it enhances the catalytic performance of the active component. Such an enhancement has been observed in the selective oxidation ofo-xylene [7-9], the oxidation of toluene to benzoic acid [10] and benzaldehyde [II], and in the ammoxidation of toluene to benzonitrile [12]. This effect is due to active phase-support interaction. In the literature various explanations have been presented as to its origin [13-16]. TiOg can also exist as rutile. Several investigators have concluded that this phase is not suitable as a support due to the weak active phase-support interaction, which results in poor spreading and the formation of crystalline Vg05 even at low loadings [16,17]. However, Cavani and coworkers [18] have found that the crystalline structure of TiOz is not important in determining the amount of vanadium oxide strongly interacting with the support. Rather, the most important factor is the degree of surface hydroxylation, which greatly depends on the method of preparation. Some years ago, Marchand and coworkers [19] reported about the preparation of another modification ofTiOg, which they called the (B)-phase. This phase has a structure similar to a sodium titanium dioxide bronze, Na^-T^Oa, prepared and investigated by Andersson and Wadsley [20]. In 1986 results were communicated showing that the (B)-modification ofTiOg is a good support for vanadium oxide, thus indicating the existence of an active phase-support interaction [21]. To our knowledge, this is the only report thus far on the use ofTiOgCB) as a catalyst support. In order to increase our knowledge on active phase support interaction in this system, we have made some preparations characterized by various methods including diffuse re- flectance FTIR spectroscopy. The loading of the active phase was varied, and ranged from a fraction of a so-called monolayer [22] to several layers. The samples were used in the ammoxidation of toluene to produce benzonitrile. Amongst aromatic nitriles, benzonitrile is of most interest and is used in the chemical industry as a versatile solvent [23]. ^.,H3 .JO, - O-CN-3"20 Experimental Preparation of support TiOg (Merck, >99%, anatase, 9 m2 g~1) was mixed with KNOa in a mole ratio KNOa/TiOg equal to 1.2:2. Since vanadium oxides are highly absorbing materials, it was necessary to dilute with KBr, giving 5-15 wt.% samples. Spectra were then recorded without further treatment in dry air free of COg. A resolution of 4 cm"1 was used, and 1000 spectra were collected for each sample. ICON analytical software from Mattson Instruments was used for spectral treatment. Diluting the samples with KBr ensures deeper penetration of the incident beam, thus increasing the contribution to the spectrum of the transmission and internal reflection components. The catalytic performance of prepared catalysts was studied in the ammoxidation of toluene to benzonitrile. Carbon oxides together with traces of benzene were formed as byproducts. At low partial pressure of NHa, benzaldehyde was also formed, together with negligible amounts of un- identified products. A differential isothermal plug flow reactor held at 370 C was used in the experiments. Over 0.1-0.5 g of catalyst, diluted with quartz of the same particle size, a total flow of 186 standard cm3 min~1 was passed. The partial pressures of the reactants were varied as follows: toluene 0.15-1.28 kPa, NHg 0-5.71 kPa and oxygen 1.42-28.5 kPa. Nitrogen was used as inert gas. Reaction products were analyzed on a Varian Vista 237 6000 gas chromatograph. A detailed description of reactor and analysis arrangement has been given elsewhere [3]. In addition, a weak band is seen at a lower wavenumber. This band is probably a V 0 V stretching band. In the case of VT-4.2, it appears at 784 cm~1. At higher loadings, the position is shifted to 764cm"1. The characteristics of these spectra are much like those reported for trivanadates [39]. In such compounds, V5"1" has a highly distorted octahedral coordination [40,41]. The octahedra are arranged in sheets, which are different from the layers in VgO^ [25]. The broadness of the strong band indicates that it originates from a material having a rather wide distribution of V==0 bond lengths. Also, the band at the lower wavenumber is very weak, which shows the absence of well-defined V 0 V distances. From the above facts it follows that the spectra in Fig. 5 originate from an amorphous phase with some short range order. Vanadium is present as V5"1" in highly distorted VOg octahedra. Conclusions Catalytic activity and selectivity of vanadium oxide can be enhanced using TiOaCB) as a support. Vanadium oxide is efficiently dispersed for loadings up to 25% coverage. For loadings corresponding to about two theoretical layers, a coverage of 80% is obtained. Complete coverage of support is not obtainable for loadings below 5-10 theoretical layers. A strong active phase-support interaction is evidenced by the formation of a monolayer composed of tetrahedrally coordinated V4'1", which cannot be oxidized to V64". At loadings up to 3 layers, 1-2 layers of tetrahedrally coordinated V6'1" is formed on top of the monolayer. When the loading is increased up to 4-5 layers, V54" is in octahedral configuration. At higher loadings, crystalline VgO^ is formed. For the ammoxidation of toluene to benzonitrile, the most active and selective catalyst is composed of 4 5 layers of vanadium oxide on top of the support. The active phase is amorphous with some short-range order, and is composed of distorted VOg octahedra.
